habtools 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

    Cube counting for 3D mesh

    cubes.Rd

    Cube counting for 3D mesh

    cubes(mesh, L0, Lmax, plot = FALSE, n = 5)

    Arguments

    mesh

    3D mesh with vertices

    L0

    The grain or resolution (i.e., smallest cube size)

    Lmax

    The grain of the biggest cube (default: cube encapsulating mesh)

    plot

    Plot number of filled cubes at different scales

    n

    The number of cube sizes to include.

    Value

    A data.frame of number of cubes (n) intersecting mesh points at different cube sizes (L) and a fractal dimension value. Note that cube size is the length of a side.

    Details

    This tool creates arrays of cubes of different sizes and counts mesh points that fall within cubes. The number of cubes for each scale can be selected (optionally), but ensure you start with 1 (i.e., a cube that encapsulates the whole mesh) and keep in mind fractals are calculated over log scales. For instance, the default cubes is a vector of doubling numbers c(1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, ...). The actual array of cubes will be these numbers to the third power. The tool will not allow the number of cubes to cause the cube size to fall below the resolution L0 of the mesh, because this will increase the chance that smaller cubes fall between mesh points and so underestimate cube counts. If L0 is not given, it will be calculated as sqrt(2) multiplied by the largest nearest neighbor distance of points. Most meshes are not perfectly fractal, and so use the plot parameter to look for scale transitions.

    References

    See also

    fd() for fractal dimension from variation method

    Examples

    cubes(mcap)
#> $cubes
#>           L0   n
#> 1 0.04247972 192
#> 2 0.06675385  88
#> 3 0.11681924  30
#> 4 0.15575898  18
#> 5 0.23363847   8
#> 6 0.46727695   1
#> 
#> $fd
#> [1] 2.140223
#> 
cubes(mcap, plot=TRUE)

#> $cubes
#>           L0   n
#> 1 0.04247972 192
#> 2 0.06675385  88
#> 3 0.11681924  30
#> 4 0.15575898  18
#> 5 0.23363847   8
#> 6 0.46727695   1
#> 
#> $fd
#> [1] 2.140223
#> 
cubes(mcap, L0 =  0.05, plot=TRUE)

#> $cubes
#>           L0   n
#> 1 0.04793157 156
#> 2 0.07988596  67
#> 3 0.11982893  29
#> 4 0.23965787   8
#> 5 0.47931573   1
#> 
#> $fd
#> [1] 2.162709
#>
